abstracts.cdata!:
This is the Implementation Completion
            Report (ICR) for the Second Power Project in Zimbabwe. The
            project's main objectives were to: (a) improve
            reliability and quality of power supply through
            rehabilitation and extension of power facilities; and (b)
            enhance institutional development of the power sub-sector
            through manpower development, technical assistance support
            for critical area of its operations, and through
            establishment of a management information system.
            Bank's performance was satisfactory. Borrower's
            performance was satisfactory. The key lessons learned were
            as follows: (i) unless supported by sound government
            policies, policy-related conditionalities in loan
            agreements, such as tariff adjustments, will not be complied
            with; (ii) government's commitment to the operational
            autonomy of the utility, particularly in the financial and
            administrative areas and including remuneration setting,
            should be a precondition to committing loan funds to power
            projects; (iii) in addition to financial viability, easy
            access to and availability of foreign exchange are critical
            to sustain Zimbabwe Electricity Supply Authority's
            (ZESA) operations; (iv) the need for detailed distribution
            study has been reinforced by the low impact of the Second
            Power distribution component on distribution losses, and
            ZESA has embarked upon a study in preparation for a new
            project; and (iv) coordination with cofinanciers,
            particularly during project implementation, should be
            improved and discussions arranged on critical issues
            affecting achievement of the overall project objectives.

abstracts.cdata!:
The Second Power Project will improve
            the efficiency and reliability of power supply through the
            rehabilitation and upgrading of power facilities.  The
            project is of high priority and consistent with the
            least-cost means of meeting the growing demand on the power
            system.  Specifically, the project comprises the
            refurbishment of generating units and auxiliaries at the
            Kariba South Bank Hydropower Station, rehabilitation and
            extension of the distribution and transmission networks.  It
            also includes provision of equipment for workshops,
            vehicles, training, power operations support, management
            information systems and computer facilities.  Lastly, the
            project entails engineering services, and studies of
            transmission network development and power system behavior
            and load frequency control.
